headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Air Products & Chemicals First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Beginning today's call is Mr. Nelson Squires, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Squires, please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Air Products & Chemicals First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Beginning today's call is Mr. Nelson Squires, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Squires, please go ahead.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kim. Good morning, and welcome to Air Products' First Quarter Earnings Teleconference. This is Nelson Squires. Today, our CFO, Paul Huck and I will review our fiscal Q1 results and provide some thoughts about next quarter. We issued our earning
componenttext: Thank you, Kim. Good morning, and welcome to Air Products' First Quarter Earnings Teleconference. This is Nelson Squires. Today, our CFO, Paul Huck and I will review our fiscal Q1 results and provide some thoughts about next quarter. We issued our earnings release this morning and it is available on our website, along with the slides for this teleconference. Please go to www.airproducts.com and click on the scrolling red banner to access the materials. Instructions for accessing the replay of this call beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time are also available on the website.Please turn to Slide 2. As always, today's teleconference will contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations regarding important risk factors. Please review the safe harbor language on this slide and at the end of today's earnings release. Now, I'll turn the call over to Paul.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nelson. As we conveyed to you in our press release this morning, our fiscal year is off to a good start. Please turn to Slide #3. For the quarter, sales decreased 1% versus prior year. This decline was primarily the result of significantly lower n
componenttext: Thanks, Nelson. As we conveyed to you in our press release this morning, our fiscal year is off to a good start. Please turn to Slide #3. For the quarter, sales decreased 1% versus prior year. This decline was primarily the result of significantly lower natural gas prices, which reduced our contractual pass-through of energy-related costs, lowering sales by 7%. Partially offsetting this was favorable currency translation, with the weaker dollar increasing sales by 4%. Underlying sales increased 2% year-on-year due to higher volumes in our Tonnage and Electronics and Performance Materials segments.Volume performance in our Merchant segment was mixed, with year-over-year gains in Asia being offset by slower economic recoveries in both the U.S. and Europe. Sequentially, sales increased 2% on higher cost pass-through. Underlying sales were down 1% on seasonality and lower Equipment and Energy sales. Operating income of $345 million increased 20% from prior year, primarily due to higher volumes, productivity and favorable currency and our operating margin of 15.9% improved by 280 basis points versus last year due to higher volumes and productivity. This significant improvement in margin in light of the modest underlying gains in sales represents of the hard work that our team has done in all aspects of our costs. We are delivering improved efficiencies in energy utilization, operating and maintenance costs and our selling and G&A costs. These are substantial savings that we can sustain and will continue to improve upon as volumes recover.For the quarter, net income increased 22% and diluted earnings per share increased by 20% each versus prior year. Return on capital employed improved sequentially. On an instantaneous basis, we have improved ROCE to 11.7%. Before I move on, just a couple of brief comments on some other items in our financial statements. Other income on our consolidated P&L was $8 million higher compared to last year, primarily due to large foreign exchange losses last year. And on the cash flow statement, our operating cash flow was impacted by $256 million in cash contributions to our pension plans. This shows up as a use of cash in payables and accrued liabilities this quarter, and is a timing issue which should even out through the rest of the fiscal year. For the entire year, we still anticipate making cash contributions of approximately $360 million. Now turning to Slide 4, for a review of the factors that affected the quarter's performance in terms of earnings per share. Our adjusted continuing operations earnings per share increased by $0.19. Higher volumes in Tonnage and Electronics and Performance Materials helped to increase earnings per share by $0.12 year on year. Pricing and energy in raw materials together were unfavorable subtracting $0.05. Cost were $0.06 favorable, reflecting our cost improvement efforts. The favorable impact to operating income from currency translation and foreign exchange was $0.07.Equity affiliated income was up $0.01. Interest expense declined on lower rates adding $0.02, a slightly higher tax rate this year cost us $0.01 and higher shares outstanding subtracted about $0.03. All in all, 20% earnings growth this quarter is a solid start to our new fiscal year despite a slow economic recovery. We are delivering the improvements we told you about from our new investments and our cost reduction efforts. Now I'll turn the call over to Nelson to review our business segment results. Nelson?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Please turn to Slide 5, Merchant Gases. Merchant Gases posted sales of $934 million, up 1% versus prior year. Underlying sales declined 5%, with volumes down 5% and pricing flat. Currency increased sales by 6% versus prior quarter, sales wer
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. Please turn to Slide 5, Merchant Gases. Merchant Gases posted sales of $934 million, up 1% versus prior year. Underlying sales declined 5%, with volumes down 5% and pricing flat. Currency increased sales by 6% versus prior quarter, sales were flat. Merchant Gases operating income of $190 million was up 11% versus prior year and up 14% sequentially.Segment operating margin of 20.3% was up 190 basis points versus prior year and 250 basis points sequentially, reflecting strong cost performance. We saw the benefits of our global cost actions from our workforce reduction, distribution efficiency and reduced plant operating costs, which in total, more than offset the decline in volume and grew margins. Loadings were flat in North America and Europe versus prior quarter and continued to improve in Asia. Signings are off to a good start in all regions. Let me now provide a few additional comments by region. Please turn to Slide 6.In North America, sales fell 11% versus prior year. Sales in the first two months of the prior-year quarter were relatively strong and this yielded a tougher comparison this year. Volumes were down 9% versus prior year, with pricing down 2%. Pricing was impacted by lower surcharge activity and lower liquid hydrogen pricing, as a result of lower natural gas costs. In Europe, sales increased 6% versus prior year. Underlying sales declined 3% with volumes down 4% and pricing adding 1%. Currency increased sales by 9%. Sales were impacted by the weak manufacturing environment but continued to be helped by pricing and increased healthcare volumes. In Asia, Merchant sales were up 13% versus last year. Underlying sales increased 8% with volumes up 11% and pricing down 3%. Currency increased sales by 5%. Volumes continued to improve across Asia, driven by steel and electronics customers. China volumes in particular were up 30% versus prior year. The price decline in Asia is principally in Argonne where last year's prices were higher due to tight supply.Please turn to Slide 7, Tonnage Gases. Sales of $698 million decreased 6% compared to last year. Volumes were up 11%. Energy and raw material pass-through decreased sales by 21% and currency increased sales by 4%. The higher volumes reflect the continuing improvement in steel and chemical end markets, as well as new plant onstreams.Sequentially, sales were up 9%, mainly due to energy and raw material pass-through. Operating income of $100 million was down 8% versus prior year and 5% sequentially, primarily due to higher maintenance spending and lower operating efficiencies. Operating margin of 14.4% decreased versus prior year and sequentially, also due to higher maintenance spending. We announced new world-scale hydrogen plants for our pipeline networks in Louisiana and Rotterdam and also announced the major upgrade and expansion of our La Porte, Texas air separation facility during the quarter.Please turn to Slide 8, Electronics & Performance Materials. Segment sales of $433 million were up 7% compared to last year. Volumes increased 11%. Pricing reduced sales by 6% and currency was 2% higher. Electronic sales were down 2% compared to last year and were flat sequentially. Sales in the quarter were impacted by lower prices and lower services and equipment sales. Electronics specialty materials sales increased 8% versus prior year and 4% sequentially. Tonnage sales were unchanged versus prior year. Performance Materials sales increased 18% versus last year and were flat sequentially, reflecting stronger Asian sales and less seasonal decline than in previous years.Segment operating income of $48 million was up 97% versus prior year, which resulted in significant improvement in margins. Sequential margins were essentially flat, reflecting lower pricing and ongoing restructuring costs. We now expect millions of square inches of silicon to grow 20% to 25% in our fiscal year and still expect the Electronics Equipment business to rebound in the second half.Please turn to Slide 9, Equipment & Energy. Sales of $109 million decreased 9% versus last year. Operating income of $8 million increased versus prior year, due to lower energy development spending, which was partially offset by restructuring costs to close a European manufacturing facility. We just announced last night a major order for three LNG heat exchangers in support of the Gorgon Project in Australia. Reflecting this order, our backlog in this segment improved to $327 million. We continue to work on other projects and expect additional award activity this year. Now I'll turn the call back over to Paul.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nelson. Now if you'll turn to Slide 10, I'd like to share my thoughts on our outlook for next quarter. Our guidance for quarter 2 is for earnings per share of $1.15 to $1.20 based on the following factors. On the positive side, we expect to see in
componenttext: Thanks, Nelson. Now if you'll turn to Slide 10, I'd like to share my thoughts on our outlook for next quarter. Our guidance for quarter 2 is for earnings per share of $1.15 to $1.20 based on the following factors. On the positive side, we expect to see increased earnings sequentially from the following areas. We expect the manufacturing economy globally to continue its gradual recovery. New plant onstreams, including a full quarter impact of our hydrogen plant to serve Marathon in Garyville, Louisiana, should contribute to next quarter's results. And in our Tonnage segment, we expect higher operating bonuses and lower maintenance costs. Partially offsetting these sequential improvements, in Asia, we expect some slowing around the lunar new year holidays. This will slow down some of the gains we've experienced in Electronics and Performance Materials and our Asian Merchant Gases business. In Equipment and Energy, we're forecasting higher development spending next quarter. And finally, we expect our tax rate will be closer to 26% in quarter 2.Please turn to Slide #11. With one quarter under our belt in fiscal 2010, we are raising our earnings per share guidance for the year to $4.75 to $4.95, anticipating growth of 17% to 22% versus prior year. We have tweaked the 2010 assumptions that we provided to you three months ago. The changes are highlighted in red on Slide #11. Overall, we expect that global manufacturing will still grow about 1% to 2% in our fiscal 2010. However, our regional forecast for Europe and Asia have changed slightly. We believe growth in Europe will be slower, as manufacturing is hampered by weak consumer spending and also a strong euro. We believe these factors will yield around a 1% decline in Europe in our fiscal 2010. Asia on the other hand, is a bright spot, and we are now forecasting growth of 8% to 9% in our fiscal 2010. Demand in the electronics market has been strong, so we're increasing our estimate for silicon growth to 20% to 25% from 10% to 15%. Our capital spending guidance remains unchanged, as well as most of our other assumptions. We are increasing our guidance for fiscal 2010 because of our continued efforts and success in the area of productivity and margin improvement.Despite the slow nature of the recovery, we remain optimistic about our prospects for growth in the future. As we noted, 2010 should be a year of strong growth for us. As we look beyond 2010, we are excited by the opportunities we have to grow, driven by alternative fuels, the focus on improving energy efficiency and the continued need for manufacturers to lower emissions and improve environmental performance. Now let me wrap up.We made solid progress towards our goal of improving operating margins and returns this quarter. And we remain committed to our goals while pursuing a large number of growth opportunities. We believe that our goal to become a low-cost supplier versus our competitors will enable us to deliver greater growth and higher returns, resulting in significant increases in shareholder value. While the global economy is still sorting itself out in 2010, we are excited about the opportunities and challenges we face. Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Kim to take your questions.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Kevin McCarthy from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Kevin McCarthy from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Merchant Gases, your operating margin there was the best in nearly 10 years,, and I was wondering if you could comment on the source of that upside. It sounded like volumes were relatively mixed in the Western world and good in Asia. And so related to tha
componenttext: Merchant Gases, your operating margin there was the best in nearly 10 years,, and I was wondering if you could comment on the source of that upside. It sounded like volumes were relatively mixed in the Western world and good in Asia. And so related to that, I was wondering if you could comment as well on the relative profitability of your business in Asia relative to the U.S. and Europe in Merchant?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: First to answer your question on the improvement in margins, if you look overall, our volume performance as you commented on, we were down in Europe and the U.S. and up in Asia. However, what was really key for our Merchant business in this quarter, reall
componenttext: First to answer your question on the improvement in margins, if you look overall, our volume performance as you commented on, we were down in Europe and the U.S. and up in Asia. However, what was really key for our Merchant business in this quarter, really has been the long journey which we've been on, on cost here. And we had very solid results year on year in cost and really quarter to quarter, which drove this volume improvement. And these things are sustainable. Things like our variable cost, improving the power efficiency of our plant, improving the distribution efficiency of our plant, lowering our fixed costs in SG&A and operation's overhead and stuff like that. And that's what drove it. As far as the relative profitability of our Asian business, our Asian business, it has good profitability in it. It's not low profitability. Our Merchant business overall, is a very profitable and a high-return business for us.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to North American pricing in Merchant, did Argonne weigh on the average of negative 2% there as it did in Asia or perhaps there are other factors at work?
componenttext: With regard to North American pricing in Merchant, did Argonne weigh on the average of negative 2% there as it did in Asia or perhaps there are other factors at work?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Argonne pricing was relatively flat year on year. Where we did see the impact as we said was in the liquid hydrogen pricing, with the change in the feedstock cost, which of course is the lower natural gas versus prior year. The other thing is, we did see
componenttext: Argonne pricing was relatively flat year on year. Where we did see the impact as we said was in the liquid hydrogen pricing, with the change in the feedstock cost, which of course is the lower natural gas versus prior year. The other thing is, we did see some of the surcharge activity that we had come off. However, with the pricing of a barrel of oil pushing back into the 70s and the high-70s, we actually feel pretty comfortable that we won't see additional surcharge erosion for the rest of the year. And frankly, stand ready to do add more surcharges if the pricing of our feedstock, i.e. diesel, does go up going forward.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question today is from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to get a little bit more color on your outlook for silicon growth. The last quarter, just a couple of months ago, 10% to 15% it's made a pretty good move here to 20% to 25%. Is it more that the first quarter was that much better and maybe the outlo
componenttext: I want to get a little bit more color on your outlook for silicon growth. The last quarter, just a couple of months ago, 10% to 15% it's made a pretty good move here to 20% to 25%. Is it more that the first quarter was that much better and maybe the outlook for the rest first of the year is sort of similar or the outlook for the rest of the year is actually that much better?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: It's more of the former. It's certainly the first quarter, saw a pretty good sustained silicon growth, probably better than expected. And certainly, with some of the companies that are already out with their earnings and information regarding their perfor
componenttext: It's more of the former. It's certainly the first quarter, saw a pretty good sustained silicon growth, probably better than expected. And certainly, with some of the companies that are already out with their earnings and information regarding their performance i.e. Intel and some others, things look to be fairly strong. Noting of course that we will see the seasonal dip because of the lunar new year of this quarter. But certainly, all indicators are that recovery here is continuing.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Paul, can you maybe give us an update on sort of bidding activity, sort of the major projects both on as merchant globally, maybe in your regions that you've seen some pick up that sort of will fill the backlog longer term?
componenttext: And then, Paul, can you maybe give us an update on sort of bidding activity, sort of the major projects both on as merchant globally, maybe in your regions that you've seen some pick up that sort of will fill the backlog longer term?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as our backlog is concerned, Mike our backlog remains in very good shape. You can see our capital spending outlook remains the same for this year, as far as things are concerned. If I take a look at bid activity, the bid activity has stayed co
componenttext: Yes, as far as our backlog is concerned, Mike our backlog remains in very good shape. You can see our capital spending outlook remains the same for this year, as far as things are concerned. If I take a look at bid activity, the bid activity has stayed constant pretty much. Four things we had a few awards in this quarter, which was good news as we will be bringing plants onstream in this year. As we look at this, the bulk of the capital spending, which we have in this year, which we're spending, it comes in the Tonnage Gas business for new plants for us. And so, we would anticipate that our backlog and workload should be solid throughout this year and going into next.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So you had two restructurings since fiscal '09 and I think that in the first one, there were supposed to be 300 people that would leave the company this quarter, which would complete that restructuring and then you had a second restructuring, which I thin
componenttext: So you had two restructurings since fiscal '09 and I think that in the first one, there were supposed to be 300 people that would leave the company this quarter, which would complete that restructuring and then you had a second restructuring, which I think was supposed to reduce the headcount by 1,150 and that was supposed to be completed I think by the end of third quarter of fiscal '10.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010

componenttext: That is correct, Jeff.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010

componenttext: And we are on track Jeff, as far as the number of people which have left for us. We still have obviously, some additional people who are going to be leaving. And so we are on track to deliver this stuff which we had. We are on schedule there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Given your silicon growth rate that you've guided to, what are the operating rates in electronics particularly in NF3 and what's the status of your Asian NF3 plant?
componenttext: Given your silicon growth rate that you've guided to, what are the operating rates in electronics particularly in NF3 and what's the status of your Asian NF3 plant?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We're operating, our operating rates are around 80% at this point. And we are actually in the process of restarting the first train in our Ulsan NF3 plant. We'll have that up this current quarter. So demand continues to rise there.
componenttext: We're operating, our operating rates are around 80% at this point. And we are actually in the process of restarting the first train in our Ulsan NF3 plant. We'll have that up this current quarter. So demand continues to rise there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is on refining. With refining margins down, light heavy spreads that have come down as well, how are you refining hydrogen volumes holding up?
componenttext: My second question is on refining. With refining margins down, light heavy spreads that have come down as well, how are you refining hydrogen volumes holding up?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And those volumes are holding up well. We are seeing the volumes, which we would expect. Our customers are taking, they are not cutting back and this gets all back on the economics of refining, is that the people who use hydrogen have better spreads on th
componenttext: And those volumes are holding up well. We are seeing the volumes, which we would expect. Our customers are taking, they are not cutting back and this gets all back on the economics of refining, is that the people who use hydrogen have better spreads on their products. It's the people who get pressed on their spreads, on their crack spreads are the refiners who do not use the hydrogen.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Dave Begleiter from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: They are very good returns for us. Our plants have every good efficiencies. We're on a pipeline system there. So you would expect it to be something, which will improve the returns of our business.
componenttext: They are very good returns for us. Our plants have every good efficiencies. We're on a pipeline system there. So you would expect it to be something, which will improve the returns of our business.

componenttext: We did have good success with that. componenttext: On the Tonnage side of the business, I was wondering if you can break out how much of the 11% year-over-year volume increase was due to new plants that started up during the quarter and maybe what kind of volume change you might have seen at your existing plants year-over-year?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: If you take a look at that, Mike, as far as new plants starting up within the quarter, when you look at year-over-year, it's also new plants which started up within this fiscal year, in 2009 also, for us which had not been started up in the thing. And the
componenttext: If you take a look at that, Mike, as far as new plants starting up within the quarter, when you look at year-over-year, it's also new plants which started up within this fiscal year, in 2009 also, for us which had not been started up in the thing. And the bulk of the increase when you look at this, it really is due to new plants.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010

componenttext: So is it fair to say that the volume of the plants that existed a year ago, was that volume at least positive year-over-year?

componenttext: Yes. Yes, it was. Yes, we have seen steel operating rates come up, and so that is in there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Electronics and Performance Materials segment, I was just wondering if you could give some comments on which product lines are seeing the most pricing pressure right now? And any thoughts on when pricing might start to improve?
componenttext: In the Electronics and Performance Materials segment, I was just wondering if you could give some comments on which product lines are seeing the most pricing pressure right now? And any thoughts on when pricing might start to improve?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: One comment I would point out is that, as you know, that's a segment that has two businesses in it. And in the Performance Materials side, we did see lower raw material costs year-on-year, which did have some impact on pricing. And so while pricing may ha
componenttext: One comment I would point out is that, as you know, that's a segment that has two businesses in it. And in the Performance Materials side, we did see lower raw material costs year-on-year, which did have some impact on pricing. And so while pricing may have gone down, margins actually stayed constant, or even improved year-on-year because of the loadings. In the Electronics side, it's the traditional high-volume products, where we have seen the pricing pressure. That pricing pressure has begun to abate, as loadings have recovered. And our expectations are that we should see continued abatement of the pricing pressure in this quarter, as the loadings continue to pick up. But it's in the key products, the large volume products, where capacity was pretty strong before the falloff. And frankly, customers have taken advantage of that position. But we do expect things again to improve there, as loading tightens up.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Gulley from Soleil Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Gulley from Soleil Securities.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010

componenttext: Talking about return on capital employed, in terms of how you measure the metric, can you give us both what you measure at the five-quarter average? And then Paul, you did supply us with the instantaneous number as well. So what about switching to an instantaneous approach and taking out that five-quarter moving average?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We actually take a look at both, Mark. And we'll be glad to supply you with both. That's not a problem for us.
componenttext: We actually take a look at both, Mark. And we'll be glad to supply you with both. That's not a problem for us.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, with respect to pricing in Merchant, we're going to talk about this a little bit more, if we can. If you take out the impact of surcharges, can you estimate what the underlying price change would have been because a surcharge is a pass-through?
componenttext: Secondly, with respect to pricing in Merchant, we're going to talk about this a little bit more, if we can. If you take out the impact of surcharges, can you estimate what the underlying price change would have been because a surcharge is a pass-through?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: A surcharge is a pass-through. Obviously, the surcharge puts in place after we incur the problem, and have to go out and remedy it. And so they do stay on longer, say, than the problem stays with us, if you will. So it's a lagging recovery. The surcharge,
componenttext: A surcharge is a pass-through. Obviously, the surcharge puts in place after we incur the problem, and have to go out and remedy it. And so they do stay on longer, say, than the problem stays with us, if you will. So it's a lagging recovery. The surcharge, our pricing was probably positive net of the surcharge impact, x the liquid hydrogen impact. It's more of a LOX-LIN [liquid oxygen-liquid nitrogen] comment, Mark. Liquid hydrogen, because of its high value, definitely has a dampening effect on the whole business and not on price.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: But there's a gas pass-through, which goes through on that too.Mark, if you take a look at overall, on the business, on the segment there, the margins were very good. Volumes held up okay. Pricing held up well for us overall. And that's the net of the cos
componenttext: But there's a gas pass-through, which goes through on that too.Mark, if you take a look at overall, on the business, on the segment there, the margins were very good. Volumes held up okay. Pricing held up well for us overall. And that's the net of the cost aspect, the cost inflation, which we saw. And then when you look at what drove that, it was really costs drove a lot of the improvement there. But it's solid fundamentals on pricing and recovery of the variable costs in there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take a question from John McNulty from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take a question from John McNulty from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to Electronics, I was a little surprised to see that sequentially, your sales were basically flat despite the semi industry actually picking up. So can you can give us some color as to what might have been happening there on a sequential basis
componenttext: With regard to Electronics, I was a little surprised to see that sequentially, your sales were basically flat despite the semi industry actually picking up. So can you can give us some color as to what might have been happening there on a sequential basis?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And what happens is we continue to see a drop in the Equipment business. So underlying there, we did see the specialty material sales pick up there sequentially. But the Equipment business is going to be -- and what we said is that we think that quarter 2
componenttext: And what happens is we continue to see a drop in the Equipment business. So underlying there, we did see the specialty material sales pick up there sequentially. But the Equipment business is going to be -- and what we said is that we think that quarter 2 here is the low for the Equipment business. And we'll start to see sales starting to pick up in quarter 3, quarter 4 and on, as we start to see some capital spending come back to the industry. But that's what drove the sequential sales.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the Merchant side, you'd talk about Merchant signings off to a good start. Can you give us a little more color as to what you're seeing in terms of new signings?
componenttext: And then on the Merchant side, you'd talk about Merchant signings off to a good start. Can you give us a little more color as to what you're seeing in terms of new signings?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing good activity across the board. And we're either on pace, or ahead of pace after a quarter in all three major regions. And it is really coming from a variety of end markets. We're starting to see continued signs of life in North America and E
componenttext: We're seeing good activity across the board. And we're either on pace, or ahead of pace after a quarter in all three major regions. And it is really coming from a variety of end markets. We're starting to see continued signs of life in North America and Europe in terms of new signings. Asia probably off to the strongest start, which is not too surprising, based on the strength of the recovery over there. A lot of the signings are in some of the key areas that we have focused on, from an application standpoint. So areas around combustion and food and some other products. And so we continue to see pretty good demand there. So I think the good news there is it is a broad-based recovery or strength in terms of new business.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Tonnage side, you'd said there were some incremental maintenance costs that hit you a little bit on the earnings side. Can you quantify what that was and how much of it disappears? Kind of looking forward or if the maintenance schedule remains rela
componenttext: On the Tonnage side, you'd said there were some incremental maintenance costs that hit you a little bit on the earnings side. Can you quantify what that was and how much of it disappears? Kind of looking forward or if the maintenance schedule remains relatively heavy for a while.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and so if you take a look at the maintenance, our heavy quarters are maintenance in the Tonnage business are normally quarters 1 and 2. We tend to have more done, rather than during the spring and the summer there. So we will see a positive impact of
componenttext: Yes, and so if you take a look at the maintenance, our heavy quarters are maintenance in the Tonnage business are normally quarters 1 and 2. We tend to have more done, rather than during the spring and the summer there. So we will see a positive impact of a few cents, a couple of cents or so, in going into quarter 2 for us on the maintenance front, John.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll take a question from Don Carson from UBS.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll take a question from Don Carson from UBS.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, wanted a follow-up on Electronics, a couple of things. I know you've had some restructuring costs there. Just what were they in the quarter? And will there be further ones in Q2? And then secondly, as you look to your loadings and Electronics with t
componenttext: Paul, wanted a follow-up on Electronics, a couple of things. I know you've had some restructuring costs there. Just what were they in the quarter? And will there be further ones in Q2? And then secondly, as you look to your loadings and Electronics with this new revised silicon outlook, do you expect loadings to turn, volume growth to turn positive in Q2? And how would you see volume growth for the balance of the year in Electronics?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, if you take a look at the restructuring costs, the restructuring costs in Electronics were probably $0.01, or a little bit more than that. And we will continue to see those costs through Q2, the wind down in quarter three, as we complete the ac
componenttext: Yes, John, if you take a look at the restructuring costs, the restructuring costs in Electronics were probably $0.01, or a little bit more than that. And we will continue to see those costs through Q2, the wind down in quarter three, as we complete the actions there for us. As far as the volumes are concerned, what we would expect is that quarter two is going to be kind of a flattish type of volume quarter for us, compared on a sequential basis. We will certainly see very good year-over-year gains in Electronics, and because quarter two also was the bottom in last year for us.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So your revised silicon outlook, that's really second-half strength that you're calling for? That's why you went from 10% [ph] to 20%?
componenttext: So your revised silicon outlook, that's really second-half strength that you're calling for? That's why you went from 10% [ph] to 20%?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the gains -- I think, is it the second half? I think a lot of the gains, which you are going to see in silicon, occur really in quarter two here. Because that was the drop-off point and the low point for the whole year. So you're going to s
componenttext: Well, a lot of the gains -- I think, is it the second half? I think a lot of the gains, which you are going to see in silicon, occur really in quarter two here. Because that was the drop-off point and the low point for the whole year. So you're going to see production on that area be the highest on a year-over-year gain for that. And after that, into quarter three and quarter four, which did pick up in the last year, we would expect also to pick up and be higher on a year-on-year basis. I don't think you're going to see a 20% gains in quarter three and quarter for year-over-year. I think your gains are going to be smaller. Your bigger gains are against quarter one and against quarter two, quarter two especially, Don.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the Performance Materials side of that segment, you had some very strong volume gains. What do margins look like relative to the segment average there, with both of those volume gains and the new Chinese facility?
componenttext: And then on the Performance Materials side of that segment, you had some very strong volume gains. What do margins look like relative to the segment average there, with both of those volume gains and the new Chinese facility?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The margins between the Electronics and the Performance Materials are about the same roughly, when you look at the individual, at the two areas. And we have seen very good improvement there, obviously. We don't have as much fixed costs of the leverage, as
componenttext: The margins between the Electronics and the Performance Materials are about the same roughly, when you look at the individual, at the two areas. And we have seen very good improvement there, obviously. We don't have as much fixed costs of the leverage, as we bring volume in and as high as it is in Electronics for us. But the new Chinese facility has enabled us to take our costs down further. So we have seen good productivity in that area also for us. The strong volumes were actually a very good sign for us, because we did not see the same dip on a seasonal basis in that business, which I think is a good sign for -- is that we could be in for a strong growth year in that area.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On Tonnage, can you flesh out a little bit the way the backlog is developing by end market, and particularly in response to higher energy costs?
componenttext: On Tonnage, can you flesh out a little bit the way the backlog is developing by end market, and particularly in response to higher energy costs?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, if you take a look at the backlog, the backlog on the Tonnage business really continues to be in two areas. On the hydrogen for refining, is a big area for us and continues to be a big area, as you can see from our announcements here. And we
componenttext: Sure. I mean, if you take a look at the backlog, the backlog on the Tonnage business really continues to be in two areas. On the hydrogen for refining, is a big area for us and continues to be a big area, as you can see from our announcements here. And we still have a lot of capital, which is going into gasification projects in China. Those gasification projects in order to produce syngas to further on and to produce other, for our products down the road on the petrochemical side. We are starting to see the steel market, and some interest pick up in the steel market in certain things. You can see we've got an order in Xingtai Steel in this quarter, which is good news for that. So the operating rates in Asia in steel are starting to raise up. And so there is opportunities, which are coming there. So that's probably the one piece of -- it not a piece of good news, but it's a change per se. It's good news, but it's a change here, as we were starting to see some activity in steel start to pick up also now.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On productivity, over the last few years, you moved away from the geographic model to a global model for addressing each of the end markets. Have you seen the productivity savings that you expected? And what's the next leg on the productivity side?
componenttext: On productivity, over the last few years, you moved away from the geographic model to a global model for addressing each of the end markets. Have you seen the productivity savings that you expected? And what's the next leg on the productivity side?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is yes, we have. As you can see from things like our SG&A, we've continued to drive that down in light of significant reductions in sales volumes for us. So we are on track on delivering all those things. The SAP system has obviously en
componenttext: The answer to that is yes, we have. As you can see from things like our SG&A, we've continued to drive that down in light of significant reductions in sales volumes for us. So we are on track on delivering all those things. The SAP system has obviously enabled that. Shared service moves have obviously enable that. I think the next area in which we are focusing a lot is on the variable costs area of improving the energy efficiency of our plants, improving the distribution efficiencies, which we see out there. And we've had very good progress in this quarter. And you can see that on the Emerging Gas business this quarter.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Sergey Vasnetsov from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Sergey Vasnetsov from Barclays Capital.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on Page 8, which shows that the price have declined by 6% in Electronics and Performance Materials segment. Given that those are really two quite a bit different markets in terms of the energy sensitivity, could you please help us to bre
componenttext: I have a question on Page 8, which shows that the price have declined by 6% in Electronics and Performance Materials segment. Given that those are really two quite a bit different markets in terms of the energy sensitivity, could you please help us to break down between the two trends?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You're talking on the Electronics and Performance Materials area? The 6% price decline is what you're referring you see there? Yes, the price decline, it was slightly higher in Electronics and slightly lower in the Performance Materials area. The Performa
componenttext: You're talking on the Electronics and Performance Materials area? The 6% price decline is what you're referring you see there? Yes, the price decline, it was slightly higher in Electronics and slightly lower in the Performance Materials area. The Performance Materials area was a back-off really on a lot of the raw material costs also there. So you've got to be careful with price on some of that, see, because some of that stuff is looking for us to continue the pass-through. And year-over-year, as Nelson said, we saw a lot of pressure in price on the Electronics Specialty Materials area, as volumes dropped a lot. That brought prices down sequentially. The prices were pretty close to flat in that area.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And would you expect prices in both Electronics and Performance Materials to be up this year?
componenttext: And would you expect prices in both Electronics and Performance Materials to be up this year?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would expect the pressure is to not be as great in both areas this year, because of improving volumes there.
componenttext: I would expect the pressure is to not be as great in both areas this year, because of improving volumes there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And we'll go next to David Manthey from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the P&L, there's this $11.4 million other income net line. And it looks like about $0.5 million of that is exchange losses. Could you tell us what else is in that line?
componenttext: When you look at the P&L, there's this $11.4 million other income net line. And it looks like about $0.5 million of that is exchange losses. Could you tell us what else is in that line?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: If you take a look at our other income line, I'll just give you a brief highlights of what sort of things go into other income for us. We've started out with -- and normally, other income, it should be a positive number for us. It includes interest income
componenttext: If you take a look at our other income line, I'll just give you a brief highlights of what sort of things go into other income for us. We've started out with -- and normally, other income, it should be a positive number for us. It includes interest income, royalty income, insurance recoveries, if we had some asset sales. So those last two tend to be onetime. And then we also put -- so all of those things tend to be a positive for us. On the negative side, we have the amortization of intangibles for us goes in there. And then the last one, which goes in there, is the foreign exchange. And that can be either a gain or loss. And last year, we had a large loss there. We usually don't have that. If you look at other income, usually, it tends to be somewhere around $7 million to $10 million positive per quarter for those things for us. So in this quarter, we are pretty much in-line with it, and last year was the unusual quarter. And foreign exchange was the difference there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then looking at how you are recognizing non-controlling interest, could you tell us how that impacted revenues and EBIT during the current quarter? And as we look at that non-controlling piece that you're kicking out after net income, how much will th
componenttext: And then looking at how you are recognizing non-controlling interest, could you tell us how that impacted revenues and EBIT during the current quarter? And as we look at that non-controlling piece that you're kicking out after net income, how much will that vary over time? Is that going to flex by a factor of two or three? Or is it just going to be up or down by $1 million or $2 million?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: That is actually, it's just a change in the position on the income statement. It used to be called minority interest. Everything above taxes did not change because of that. It stayed the same for that. It's just the way in which it's put out there. It was
componenttext: That is actually, it's just a change in the position on the income statement. It used to be called minority interest. Everything above taxes did not change because of that. It stayed the same for that. It's just the way in which it's put out there. It was something, which all companies went to pretty much in fiscal 2009 because it was effective for fiscal year, starting after 15 December 2008. Our fiscal year started early, so we adopted this late. And so it doesn't really change anything. It just changes the bottom end of the statement on the presentation.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Amy Zhang from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Amy Zhang from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, it's Bob Koort. Can you talk a little bit about the Equity Affiliates? Is that pretty uniform, consistent performance across those? Or are there some areas, where you've seen strength? And other areas, where it's been a little bit weaker?
componenttext: Actually, it's Bob Koort. Can you talk a little bit about the Equity Affiliates? Is that pretty uniform, consistent performance across those? Or are there some areas, where you've seen strength? And other areas, where it's been a little bit weaker?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the areas and the large affiliates which we have, the two large ones are Italy and Mexico. And so their economies pretty much reflect their region. And then results pretty much reflect our regions. So if you look at Italy, that is having a tough
componenttext: As far as the areas and the large affiliates which we have, the two large ones are Italy and Mexico. And so their economies pretty much reflect their region. And then results pretty much reflect our regions. So if you look at Italy, that is having a tougher time because of Europe. Mexico is more tied to the U.S. there. So it's started to see some recovery come back here. And then our affiliates in Asia, which are India and Thailand, and they are obviously getting better and seeing the boom in Asia, which we're seeing. Or the strong recovery, sorry [ph], I wouldn't call it a boom yet.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On Merchant Gases, Paul, I guess I'm trying to come up with some sort of algorithm that makes sense. But it looks like pricing and volume don't have any correlation, looking at the regional data you provide. Can you just talk a little bit about what's goi
componenttext: On Merchant Gases, Paul, I guess I'm trying to come up with some sort of algorithm that makes sense. But it looks like pricing and volume don't have any correlation, looking at the regional data you provide. Can you just talk a little bit about what's going on with pricing in the regions?  And then if prices remained flat today on all new contracts, how long would it take before you would roll off any negative influence of the last 18 months, in terms of pricing?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start there. Part of this is it's a combination of the product mix, and it's a combination of the sizes of the various businesses that get us to the answer. If you look at some of the key products, if I start in North America, the main impact there
componenttext: Let me start there. Part of this is it's a combination of the product mix, and it's a combination of the sizes of the various businesses that get us to the answer. If you look at some of the key products, if I start in North America, the main impact there was hydrogen, as we said earlier. All the products were probably flat to slightly up. And in Europe, we saw more stronger improvements. We have seen more significant energy increases over there. We've gone out more aggressively. And we have seen pretty much stronger pricing across the board, which is yielding the improvement. Realize, of course, in Europe, we also have a Packaged Gas business. And we have been very busy at price actions in the Packaged Gas business for the last couple of quarters, and that is showing some impact. In Asia, we have seen basically pressure from two sources; one, the Argonne, as I mentioned before. But then also, and this is partly the same answer, a fair amount of new capacity has come on stream in Asia in the last several months. These were projects that have been in execution for a number of years, and just coming on stream. And that, coupled with the lower demand, certainly has some pricing challenges out there. But all within what we've expected so far this year, Bob, nothing really unusual there. In terms of the cycle of this, we would expect that the surcharges that we have in place probably remain pretty steady for the next couple of quarters, even if it's hard to predict where diesel is going to be. But we've largely converted any energy base surcharges in the permanent price at this point. And so we continue to do that with some of the older surcharges for diesel fuel. With regards to quality of new signings, we have actually seen that stabilized, because demand has begun to pick up. And then one of the issues we saw the same a year ago quarter, is there weren't too many deals going down. Because everyone was sort of holding their decision  making, to see where the economy bottomed out. And so there were some less-than-desirable deals out there. We've seen that begin to reverse itself with the quality of signings actually picking up. And so at the end of the day, we think the pricing impact there, as that comes on stream, will be net positive. Although it's such a small fraction of the entire enterprise, it will be hard to see it.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, I think an important thing to remember is that if you just look at pricing and you don't look at the underlying things, which are happening on the variable costs, you missed half of the story with those things. Because on power costs and diesel
componenttext: Yes, Bob, I think an important thing to remember is that if you just look at pricing and you don't look at the underlying things, which are happening on the variable costs, you missed half of the story with those things. Because on power costs and diesel costs and stuff like that, we are going to push our prices up if we see those things. And our contracts allow us to do that. And so you could see pricing happen. Consequently, also as they come down, we're going to see prices come down. And that's kind of the stuff, which you're seeing here in the U.S. and Europe for us.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll hear next from Richard Ong from Eagle Capital Management.
componenttext: We'll hear next from Richard Ong from Eagle Capital Management.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to Tonnage Gases, if you look at last year's existing plans, I would imagine that chemicals are probably shut down for the most part. So why would maintenance costs be higher this quarter versus last year's quarter, when you basically have more
componenttext: Going back to Tonnage Gases, if you look at last year's existing plans, I would imagine that chemicals are probably shut down for the most part. So why would maintenance costs be higher this quarter versus last year's quarter, when you basically have more downtime where you could have done more maintenance? And is the operating income decline mainly a function of the newer plants operating at essentially losses causing that? Or is there something else going on the operating income line?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: First, Richard, the thing which steel and chemical plants are not the major source of our sales and profits for us. If you have to look at us, when you look at us, on the on-site area, we are 2/3-plus really in the hydrogen area. And so the operating rate
componenttext: First, Richard, the thing which steel and chemical plants are not the major source of our sales and profits for us. If you have to look at us, when you look at us, on the on-site area, we are 2/3-plus really in the hydrogen area. And so the operating rates for those plants was high throughout this time period. So we did not see our customers -- and shutting down. So the maintenance, which occurred, really corresponded to our customers taking downtime on the hydrogen area. And that's what you're seeing in this quarter. So that answers that question. When you look at the operating income decline, we had good gains in volumes for those things. So we had a positive impact of volumes on there than we had a negative impact on the maintenance costs. And then on the operating efficiencies, which we talked about, the thing which we have is we have a guarantee on the power and the gas consumption at our plants for converting into hydrogen or oxygen or whatever product we're making. We typically operate more efficiently than that. And we did this quarter. It's just that the price of gas is lower this quarter than it was a year ago. And so those operating efficiencies, which we get, are not worth as much.

componenttext: Yes, the CapEx numbers -- and those are included in the guidance,  which we have out there. They are not huge, Mark. We have those type of things happening. But it's not going to change the curve on the CapEx for us. It's under $100 million a year, could do that easily.

componenttext: Now is that increasing? I guess where I'm going to is that, is that  an increasing trend? Are we going to see more and more, maybe as the asset base ages? Is it necessary to put more into efficiency going forward?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think you're going to see a tremendous amount, Mark, going in there. I think as we look at this, a lot of it just comes on how you go out and run the plants, too. A lot of it gets around the way in which we run our plants. And also, the distributi
componenttext: I don't think you're going to see a tremendous amount, Mark, going in there. I think as we look at this, a lot of it just comes on how you go out and run the plants, too. A lot of it gets around the way in which we run our plants. And also, the distribution aspect is the other aspect of this. So it's not only the variable cost of power and gas in the plants, but it's also the improvements, which we make in driving the product we deliver around less.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, you beat by, maybe $0.05 or so, in terms of your first quarter guidance. You raised your guidance for the full year by only about $0.05. That would suggest the other three quarters are going to be pretty much on plan. Could there be an elemen
componenttext: And finally, you beat by, maybe $0.05 or so, in terms of your first quarter guidance. You raised your guidance for the full year by only about $0.05. That would suggest the other three quarters are going to be pretty much on plan. Could there be an element of conservatism in that outlook?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-22-2010
componenttextpreview: As what you can see, is we still have a lot of concerns compared to a lot of other people around the economy, the manufacturing economy. I mean a lot of people have given me comments about -- and why we think the manufacturing economy only grosses as litt
componenttext: As what you can see, is we still have a lot of concerns compared to a lot of other people around the economy, the manufacturing economy. I mean a lot of people have given me comments about -- and why we think the manufacturing economy only grosses as little as it does for us this year. And we are trying to be cautious in our approach there. The other thing which you've got to realize is that, I'm also comparing year-on-year on the fiscal year. And that's a little bet [ph]. So I mean, if you look at this, we have the capacity. We have all the ability, if the economy gets better, to capture that upside at a very nice margin for us. So I continue to be cautious, and John continues to be cautious in our approach here to moving forward. And so yes, it could be an upside for us if the economy does better.
