componenttext: How about something that would be bigger and something you might put in the Gulf Coast then?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you take a plant which goes into the Gulf Coast, that can probably add 3% or so in sales growth.
componenttext: If you take a plant which goes into the Gulf Coast, that can probably add 3% or so in sales growth.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: To the entire Tonnage?
componenttext: To the entire Tonnage?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: To the entire segment, yes.
componenttext: To the entire segment, yes.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give me some sense on Electronics and Performance, how long do you expect these very strong sequential numbers to continue and maybe talk a little bit about the seasonality there?
componenttext: Can you give me some sense on Electronics and Performance, how long do you expect these very strong sequential numbers to continue and maybe talk a little bit about the seasonality there?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the Electronics and Performance Materials, there is a sequential uptick from Quarter 2 to Quarter 3 and we would expect to see that. And so I would expect to see a good Quarter 3 and a good Q4. And then we'll probably see a start of the sequenti
componenttext: As far as the Electronics and Performance Materials, there is a sequential uptick from Quarter 2 to Quarter 3 and we would expect to see that. And so I would expect to see a good Quarter 3 and a good Q4. And then we'll probably see a start of the sequential down in Quarter 1. You'll realize that the business here took the highest hit from the recession. And so it's going to have the strongest bounce back, also coming through here.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to add Bob, this is Nelson. Certainly, the improved automobile production has helped the Performance Materials business. And as I said during the call, or during the prepared remarks, one of the things that was very encouraging was we did take a li
componenttext: I want to add Bob, this is Nelson. Certainly, the improved automobile production has helped the Performance Materials business. And as I said during the call, or during the prepared remarks, one of the things that was very encouraging was we did take a little bit of a volume hit during lunar new year but we were up sequentially. So customer operating rates have continued to improve and key customer rates are over 80% now. So that number we think as Paul said, continues to track up for the next two quarters.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question, Laurence Alexander with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question, Laurence Alexander with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give updates on how you're thinking about the hydrogen market, both in terms of any large projects coming which might be up for bid over the next four to six quarters? And also what you think the longer-term taker for demand might be or the addr
componenttext: Could you give updates on how you're thinking about the hydrogen market, both in terms of any large projects coming which might be up for bid over the next four to six quarters? And also what you think the longer-term taker for demand might be or the addressable taker for in our products?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we take a look on the hydrogen area, we see do see a move outside the U.S. into places like Asia, the Middle East for us. We currently are actively involved in projects out there. And so we think that the growth for hydrogen, is still going to be somew
componenttext: If we take a look on the hydrogen area, we see do see a move outside the U.S. into places like Asia, the Middle East for us. We currently are actively involved in projects out there. And so we think that the growth for hydrogen, is still going to be somewhere around 8% to 10% range. But the shift is going to be for the bulk of the market to be outside of the U.S. as far as work is concerned. And less growth within North America in the near term. There's still the oil sands, which could produce more growth if that gets developed.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the pace of outsourcing activity to be the same in Asia as in the U.S.?
componenttext: And do you expect the pace of outsourcing activity to be the same in Asia as in the U.S.?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the outsourcing in Asia, we think on the majors, we think it's going to be doable. I think you're going to see some JVs in China to make these things happen also.
componenttext: On the outsourcing in Asia, we think on the majors, we think it's going to be doable. I think you're going to see some JVs in China to make these things happen also.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And separately, can you give a little bit more detail on demand trends in Europe, particular end markets that might be stronger or are recovering earlier? And are there any other areas where you're surprised by how weak it is?
componenttext: And separately, can you give a little bit more detail on demand trends in Europe, particular end markets that might be stronger or are recovering earlier? And are there any other areas where you're surprised by how weak it is?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: For us, in the European business, the place in which we have seen the lowest margin declines is packaged gas. Packaged gas is a late cycle as far as the business is concerned. And so our bulk market, and our bulk volumes have been doing pretty well and co
componenttext: For us, in the European business, the place in which we have seen the lowest margin declines is packaged gas. Packaged gas is a late cycle as far as the business is concerned. And so our bulk market, and our bulk volumes have been doing pretty well and coming back. A lot of business in the food area has been performing well for us. If you look at the geography of it, the East and the North are probably better than the South in Europe. The South is still pretty much in a tough recession at this point in time.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Mann with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Mann with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that the operating below the take or pay minimum in the quarter. Did that ratio change at all from the first quarter to the second quarter? So did you grow volumes in your plants take or pay minimum? What I'm trying to get is whether or not
componenttext: You mentioned that the operating below the take or pay minimum in the quarter. Did that ratio change at all from the first quarter to the second quarter? So did you grow volumes in your plants take or pay minimum? What I'm trying to get is whether or not as you go forward, do you feel better incremental margin for coming from coming in from tonnage because you more take or pay minimum, if that makes sense?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, for the people operating above the take or pay, we probably have some of that. The place which is going to impact us and the most of our products is still on the hydrogen area for us. And that's the bulk of our business in the tonnage area. And so w
componenttext: Paul, for the people operating above the take or pay, we probably have some of that. The place which is going to impact us and the most of our products is still on the hydrogen area for us. And that's the bulk of our business in the tonnage area. And so we really didn't see our customers go to the mins in that area. Our customers have still continued to cooperate. Our volumes year on year in that area are about flat with those things, if I take out the new plants when you look at it. We have seen on the steel on sites, we have seen increases in the volumes. Realize that for a lot of our customers in steel, it is a take or pay contract. It is a type of contract. I don't pay for the plant and then I pace per product charge. I typically make all of my money on the payment for the plant and not on the product charge that pass through the energy. So I don't have a lot of volatility in the business introduced by the steel aspect of it.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the, if you put in your volumes from Q1 into Q2 trying to bring them up to the take or pay minimum, you're not going to see a revenue on margin impact. And if you start to grow volumes going into Q3, I'm assuming we'll start to see a better revenue and
componenttext: On the, if you put in your volumes from Q1 into Q2 trying to bring them up to the take or pay minimum, you're not going to see a revenue on margin impact. And if you start to grow volumes going into Q3, I'm assuming we'll start to see a better revenue and margin impact.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What happens Paul, is actually and when a person operates at the men's, he doesn't pay the product charge which is just a pass through. And so actually, on the sales dollars come down, the profits tend not to come down, right. And therefore, what happens
componenttext: What happens Paul, is actually and when a person operates at the men's, he doesn't pay the product charge which is just a pass through. And so actually, on the sales dollars come down, the profits tend not to come down, right. And therefore, what happens is that the margins as they loading starts to occur up to the take or pay and above it is margins tend to decline a little bit with that. The bulk of the profits in this business is earned by installing a plant, having a plant operate for the customers. And that's where we operate at.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking forward to sort of 2011, based on your backlog at the moment and the orders you're bidding for, would you expect CapEx to increase in 2011 or decrease or stay roughly the same?
componenttext: Just looking forward to sort of 2011, based on your backlog at the moment and the orders you're bidding for, would you expect CapEx to increase in 2011 or decrease or stay roughly the same?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, I would expect that my CapEx probably would be the same to up in 2011. A lot of that is going to be dependent upon award activity here in the last six months.
componenttext: Right now, I would expect that my CapEx probably would be the same to up in 2011. A lot of that is going to be dependent upon award activity here in the last six months.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Manthey with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Manthey with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can or will estimate the volume impact from new tonnage contracts in the third quarter?
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can or will estimate the volume impact from new tonnage contracts in the third quarter?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We tend to look at the contracts which will have come on stream in Quarter 2 and Quarter 3. We basically have the Exxon job, and the corporate plant coming on stream. And they will have a small growth here, probably they add $0.01 or so to earnings.
componenttext: We tend to look at the contracts which will have come on stream in Quarter 2 and Quarter 3. We basically have the Exxon job, and the corporate plant coming on stream. And they will have a small growth here, probably they add $0.01 or so to earnings.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of volume, a couple percent or?
componenttext: And in terms of volume, a couple percent or?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then second, in terms of your cost reduction efforts, can you talk about where you stand today, maybe sort of a run rate versus what's left over the next 12 months or so?
componenttext: And then second, in terms of your cost reduction efforts, can you talk about where you stand today, maybe sort of a run rate versus what's left over the next 12 months or so?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On those efforts, we will be taking those efforts and wrapping them up at the end of Quarter 3. So we are pretty well done. The bulk of the efforts really occurred in the last half of 2009. We've had continued efforts especially in Europe as we've been re
componenttext: On those efforts, we will be taking those efforts and wrapping them up at the end of Quarter 3. So we are pretty well done. The bulk of the efforts really occurred in the last half of 2009. We've had continued efforts especially in Europe as we've been restricted as to how many people we can let go going forward here. So we're probably about 90% complete or so right now.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: But maybe a little bit more than that in terms of inertia. . .
componenttext: But maybe a little bit more than that in terms of inertia. . .

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's true, David. I think one of the things that you should understand is we're going to continue on this cost effort going forward. So we have the program but we always have an effort on cost. So cost and this drive for us to be low cost is going t
componenttext: And that's true, David. I think one of the things that you should understand is we're going to continue on this cost effort going forward. So we have the program but we always have an effort on cost. So cost and this drive for us to be low cost is going to continue. We measure ourselves against our competitors. Our competitors are good. They're working on the same things they are. We intend to beat them on this thing. And be the best industrial gas company in regard to cost and the position which we have. And so we are very serious about that we would continue to take actions on cost throughout our future.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Edward Yang with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from Edward Yang with Oppenheimer.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just would like to understand your thinking on acquisitions in general. I saw that you made a small French acquisition and what was the rationale for that and are you evaluating other transactions outside of Airgas?
componenttext: Just would like to understand your thinking on acquisitions in general. I saw that you made a small French acquisition and what was the rationale for that and are you evaluating other transactions outside of Airgas?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the opportunity in which we had there, Ed, it was an opportunity in France. It fit extremely well with our current business in the area. So it's a great opportunity. It's something which we have done in the past in the business in Europe. And it's hel
componenttext: And the opportunity in which we had there, Ed, it was an opportunity in France. It fit extremely well with our current business in the area. So it's a great opportunity. It's something which we have done in the past in the business in Europe. And it's helped our business in Europe grow and increase the profitability and scale the business. So that was the design of that. If those opportunities come up again in the future, we will continue to pursue them. Right now as far as acquisition activity, we continue to evaluate some. There is nothing really hot beyond Airgas on buying a company. The other thing which you should know is we continue to look at on buying plants which we have sold or other people have sold in the past and bringing them in as sale of gas from the sale of equipment work at the job. And we continue to make progress in that. The type of projects which we look for in that area are ones which are going to lead to growth in the future. We bought the Corpus Christi plant in the hydrogen in Texas reason why is because we were able to get a good deal on the plant plus and then we also see more product being required in the future so we saw an opportunity to invest and build the franchise there. On the Xingtai Steel, we bought some plans but we also got an order for that to build the franchise in that area. And so it's those types of opportunities which we look at. We probably have two, three around the world in which we are pursuing right now which are looking good for us in the future.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: But staying within the U.S. in terms of the packaged gas, half of the market in the U.S. is still 50% owned by independents. If you do decide to go in another direction from Airgas, it seems like you're very committed to Airgas, would you look to replicat
componenttext: But staying within the U.S. in terms of the packaged gas, half of the market in the U.S. is still 50% owned by independents. If you do decide to go in another direction from Airgas, it seems like you're very committed to Airgas, would you look to replicate on Airgas type of acquisition strategy? Would you be interested in buying independent packaged gas distributors with the knowledge in mind that it would take a considerable amount of time to get scale in that market?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly -- if the Airgas transaction does not go forward, we will continue to work to make sure that we serve the distribution segment of the market, whether we do that via acquisitions or whether we do that via contracts with those people or did som
componenttext: We certainly -- if the Airgas transaction does not go forward, we will continue to work to make sure that we serve the distribution segment of the market, whether we do that via acquisitions or whether we do that via contracts with those people or did something else, which would be something which would disclose at that point in time.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's your FX assumption in your 2010 guidance? And if you would look forward to 2011, what kind of euro exchange rate would you be using?
componenttext: What's your FX assumption in your 2010 guidance? And if you would look forward to 2011, what kind of euro exchange rate would you be using?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't try to go out and predict the exchange rates at the close of the quarter, we were looking at for Quarter 3 and Quarter 4, for the euro to be around $1.35 or so. When you get that for the year, that probably takes us close to $1.40 or so.
componenttext: I don't try to go out and predict the exchange rates at the close of the quarter, we were looking at for Quarter 3 and Quarter 4, for the euro to be around $1.35 or so. When you get that for the year, that probably takes us close to $1.40 or so.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Roberts with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Roberts with Buckingham Research.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The European Packaged Gas, weak volumes. Is that a leading business or a lagging business relative to the economy? And I ask that because at least in North America, I think you used to be a leading business for Airgas and kind of lagging the cycle because
componenttext: The European Packaged Gas, weak volumes. Is that a leading business or a lagging business relative to the economy? And I ask that because at least in North America, I think you used to be a leading business for Airgas and kind of lagging the cycle because of the credit issues for small customers and so forth. So what can we tell from your European Packaged Gas business?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, packaged gases has always been a lag. It has never been a lead in any of the areas. And the reason why is about a quarter of the volumes go into investment type of activities, construction type markets. Construction always lags coming out of the rec
componenttext: John, packaged gases has always been a lag. It has never been a lead in any of the areas. And the reason why is about a quarter of the volumes go into investment type of activities, construction type markets. Construction always lags coming out of the recession. And so you always see that happening. Plus the other thing that's happened, if you charge on the cylinders, the customers return them late. They bring them back and you revenues drop towards the end of the recession as the customers. And then it takes a while for those revenues to come back up and build back up. But packaged gas as the market, has always been a lag business. And it lags in the European economy also.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Peter Butler with Glendale Investments.
componenttext: And our next question is from Peter Butler with Glendale Investments.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys had me a bit confused here. I thought the goal with acquisitions and with the stock in general is to increase the earnings per share, boost the ROCE and return more cash to the owners. And this Airgas transaction looks like it does none of these
componenttext: You guys had me a bit confused here. I thought the goal with acquisitions and with the stock in general is to increase the earnings per share, boost the ROCE and return more cash to the owners. And this Airgas transaction looks like it does none of these things and I was around when you guys unloaded this business, the packaged gas business, and you said good riddance and you had a lot of good reasons to say goodbye that still look valid. I'm wondering, what's going on? Airgas shareholders get the cash and Air Products shareholders get shafted here with the stock down.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, I will tell you that the Air Products shareholders are not going to get shafted by this deal. There's a lot of concern over how much Air Products is going to pay. And the uncertainty of the transaction and that's what has temporarily taken our stoc
componenttext: Peter, I will tell you that the Air Products shareholders are not going to get shafted by this deal. There's a lot of concern over how much Air Products is going to pay. And the uncertainty of the transaction and that's what has temporarily taken our stock price down. We have a very good plan to go out and achieve the cost savings which we have put out there. We also have a good understanding of the business and how it has improved since the time in which we sold it. We think there are a lot of good opportunities for us going forward here. We didn't think the packaged gases was a bad business. The business which we sold did not have scale. This deal creates value. We are going to be disciplined on price. You will continue to see that. And we will make this pay off for the Air Products shareholders.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you sold it, you said goodbye with good riddance to a mature North American centric business with slow growth and it was recognized as being a low-quality business that would command a low-quality price earnings ratio. And all that still looks valid.
componenttext: When you sold it, you said goodbye with good riddance to a mature North American centric business with slow growth and it was recognized as being a low-quality business that would command a low-quality price earnings ratio. And all that still looks valid. I'm wondering, what the hell do we need this thing for?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, if you took a look at the dynamics of the business at that point in time, it was largely unconsolidated at that point in time. Since that time period, there has been a lot of consolidation by Airgas and a lot of consolidation by in that. And the bu
componenttext: Peter, if you took a look at the dynamics of the business at that point in time, it was largely unconsolidated at that point in time. Since that time period, there has been a lot of consolidation by Airgas and a lot of consolidation by in that. And the business has improved substantially. We see the opportunity here to improve the margins within the business and maintain those margins and continue to grow. We also see the opportunity to take that model and take it into the Asia market. And with the Airgas transaction, that will help us do that.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010

componenttext: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. Mr. Squires, I'd like to turn the conference back to you for closing remarks.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Air Products & Chemicals Second Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Beginning today's call is Mr. Nelson Squires, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Squires, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Air Products & Chemicals Second Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Beginning today's call is Mr. Nelson Squires, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Squires, you may begin.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tricka. Good morning, and welcome to Air Products Second Quarter Earnings Teleconference. This is Nelson Squires. Today, our CFO, Paul Huck and I will review our fiscal Q2 results and provide some thoughts about the rest of the year. We issued
componenttext:
Thank you, Tricka. Good morning, and welcome to Air Products Second Quarter Earnings Teleconference. This is Nelson Squires. Today, our CFO, Paul Huck and I will review our fiscal Q2 results and provide some thoughts about the rest of the year. We issued our earnings release this morning and it is available on our website, along with the slides for this teleconference. Please go to www.airproducts.com and click on the scrolling red banner to access the materials. Instructions for accessing the replay of this call, beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time, are also available on the website.
Please turn to slides 2 and 3. As always, today's teleconference will contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations regarding important risk factors. Please review the safe harbor language on these slides and at the end of today's earnings release. Now, I'll turn the call over to Paul.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nelson. With half of our fiscal year 2010 behind us, we are well on our way to delivering on our financial targets. Please turn to Slide #4. This slide highlights of some of the key financial metrics and the progress that we have made coming out o
componenttext:
Thanks, Nelson. With half of our fiscal year 2010 behind us, we are well on our way to delivering on our financial targets. Please turn to Slide #4. This slide highlights of some of the key financial metrics and the progress that we have made coming out of the recession. Just a bit of history, if you take a look at the left side of the slide, you'll see the improvements that we have made as an organization over the five-year period before the recession. We have moved our margin up a couple hundred basis points and we improved our return on capital by just short of 400 basis points. The other thing you can see on the right side of this slide is the impact of the global recession on the first half of our fiscal 2009. During that time, we took a number of significant actions to position us appropriately coming out of the recession. Our results show the progress we have made since then and the impact of those actions on our first half results and the sequential improvement that we're continuing to make as an organization. Sales continued to improve as our underlying sales growth, which turned positive last quarter continued to recover. Year-to-date, underlying sales growth is up 6%. Our operating margin in the first half has improved to 16% and we remain on track to deliver on our 17% goal in fiscal 2011.
Earnings growth remains strong and as you've already seen in our press release this morning, we raised our full-year earnings per share guidance again this quarter. We now expect earnings per share growth to exceed 20% this fiscal year. And most importantly, we continue to drive return on capital employed higher, striving to keep our return on capital three to five points above our cost of capital across this cycle. This lower cost structure makes us even more competitive and well positioned to grow faster with higher returns.
Please turn to Slide #5 for a quick look at the current quarter. Sales increased 15% versus prior year. Underlying sales increased 9% year on year due to higher volumes in our Electronics and Performance Materials segment and our Tonnage segment. Volume performance in our Merchant segment continue to be mixed, with strength in Asia being offset by slower recovery in both the U.S. and Europe. Higher natural gas prices, which raised our contractual pass through of energy-related costs, increased sales by 2%. Additionally, favorable currency translation from a weaker dollar increased sales by 4%. Sequentially, sales increased 3%, with underlying sales up 3% on volume growth across all business segments versus the prior quarter. Operating income of $364 million increased 40% from prior year, primarily due to higher volumes and better cost performance. As a result, our operating margin of 16.2% improved by 290 basis points versus last year. This improvement in margin can be sustained and should continue to improve as volumes recover.
Looking forward, we still have significant operating leverage available. For the quarter, net income increased 41% and diluted earnings per share increased by 38%, each versus prior year. Return on capital employed improved 70 basis points sequentially to 11.6%. On an instantaneous or run rate basis, we have improved return on capital employed to 12.1%.
Turning to Slide 6 for a review of the factors that affected the quarter's performance in terms of earning per share. Our adjusted continuing operations earnings per share increased by $0.34. Higher volumes in Electronics and Performance Materials and Tonnage helped to increase earnings per share by $0.29 year-on-year. Pricing, energy and raw materials altogether were unfavorable, subtracting $0.09. Costs were $0.12 favorable, reflecting our significant cost improvement efforts. The favorable impact to operating income from currency translation and foreign exchange was $0.05. Equity affiliate income was up $0.02. Noncontrolling interest was up, lowering EPS by $0.02 and higher shares outstanding subtracted about $0.03. 
In summary, we generated solid financial results again this quarter. We are delivering on the improvements we told you about from our new investments and our cost reduction efforts. Now I'll turn the call over to Nelson to review our business segment results. Nelson?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Please turn to Slide 7, Merchant Gases. Merchant Gases posted sales of $922 million, up 6% versus prior year. Underlying sales were flat, with volumes up 1% and pricing down 1%. Currency increased sales by 6%. Versus prior quarter, underlyin
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Please turn to Slide 7, Merchant Gases. Merchant Gases posted sales of $922 million, up 6% versus prior year. Underlying sales were flat, with volumes up 1% and pricing down 1%. Currency increased sales by 6%. Versus prior quarter, underlying sales were up modestly due to strong performance in Asia and were negatively impacted by currency. Merchant Gases operating income of $178 million was up 14% versus prior year and down 6% sequentially. Segment operating margin of 19.3% was up 140 basis points versus prior year and down 100 basis points sequentially. Year-on-year income and margins benefited from higher volumes and improved cost performance. Sequential operating income and margins were impacted by poor weather conditions in Europe in January as well as Lunar New Year in Asia. Signings at the midyear point are on track to meet our full year targets in all regions. Let me now provide a few additional comments by region. Please turn to Slide 8.
In North America, sales improved 2% versus prior year. Volumes led by stronger liquid argon and liquid hydrogen sales were up 5% versus prior year. Pricing continued to be impacted by lower surcharge activity and lower liquid hydrogen pricing as a result of cost pass-through of lower natural gas costs. LOX/LIN loading remained in the mid-70s. In Europe, sales increased 6% versus prior year. Underlying sales declined 2%, with volumes down 2% and pricing flat. Currency increased sales by 8%. Sales were impacted by the weak manufacturing environment in Southern Europe but were helped by increased healthcare volumes. LOX/LIN loadings also remain in the mid-70s. 
In Asia, merchant sales were up 24% versus last year. Underlying sales increased 18% with volumes up 22% and pricing down 4%. Currency increased sales by 6%. Volumes continued to rebound significantly across the region, driven by steel, electronics and bulk hydrogen customers. March was the best month in our history in the region and our volumes this quarter surpassed our 2008 peak. The price decline is primarily tied to lower liquid argon pricing as supply has rebounded quicker than demand as new piggyback sources have been brought onstream. 
Please turn to Slide 9, Tonnage Gases. Sales of $757 million increased 21% compared to last year. Volumes were up 11%. Energy and raw material pass through increased sales by 6% and currency increased sales by 4%. The higher volumes reflect the continuing improvement in steel and chemical end markets as well as new plant onstreams. Sequentially, sales were up 8% due to energy and raw material pass through. Operating income of $107 million was up 9% versus prior year and 7% sequentially, primarily due to higher base volumes and a new plant startups. Operating margin of 14.2% decreased versus prior year due to higher energy and raw material pass through. Refinery hydrogen, excluding new onstreams, was flat versus prior year. We expect volumes to improve in the second half of the year as the new facilities achieve higher operating rates and spot demand increases. Bidding on new projects remains active and we expect additional awards for new business this year. The segment will also see the benefit of several major startups in Quarters 3 and 4. Paul will have more to say about this in his outlook.
Please turn to Slide 10, Electronics and Performance Materials. Segment sales of $451 million were up 36% compared to last year. Volumes increased 38%. Pricing reduced sales by 4% and currency was 2% higher. Each division saw sequential volume gains. Electronic sales were up 28% compared to last year and 4% sequentially. Sales in the quarter were up significantly versus the low point a year ago and were better than expected sequentially. Electronics Specialty Materials sales increased 56% versus prior year and 1% sequentially. Tonnage sales were 10% higher versus prior year. In addition, we are seeing the expected pick up in orders for our Equipment business as new fab CapEx is growing once again. Performance Materials sales increased 45% versus last year and 4% sequentially, reflecting stronger volumes. The volume recovery in the segment was initially led by Asia, but we are now seeing improvement in both North America and Europe. Segment operating income of $57 million was up substantially versus prior year, which resulted in a significant improvement in margins. Sequential margins improved 140 basis points, reflecting stronger volumes and solid cost control. Progress on the Electronics restructuring efforts continued during the quarter. We will see a larger impact to margins in our third quarter as we incur costs to complete these efforts. We now expect millions of square inches of silicon to grow by approximately 30% in our fiscal year.
Please turn to Slide 11, Equipment and Energy. Sales of $119 million decreased 7% versus last year on lower air separation unit sales. Operating income of $18 million increased versus prior year due to higher LNG activity. Our backlog is rising due to the previously announced Gorgon LNG order. And we will soon be formally announcing another major LNG order with ExxonMobil for their Papua New Guinea project, which was received during the quarter. Now I'll turn the call back over to Paul.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nelson. Now if you'll please turn to Slide 12. I'd like to share our thoughts on our outlook. Our guidance for quarter three is for earnings per share of $1.25 to $1.29 based on the following factors. On the positive side, we expect to see increas
componenttext:
Thanks, Nelson. Now if you'll please turn to Slide 12. I'd like to share our thoughts on our outlook. Our guidance for quarter three is for earnings per share of $1.25 to $1.29 based on the following factors. On the positive side, we expect to see increased earnings sequentially from the following areas. We expect the manufacturing economy globally to continue its gradual recovery. This, along with some seasonal boost, should result in higher sequential volumes in the Merchant Gases and the Electronics and Performance Materials segments. 
New plant onstreams and supply contracts, including the full quarter impact of our new hydrogen plant in Corpus Christi, Texas and our increased supply at ExxonMobil at Baytown, Texas will contribute to next quarter's Tonnage results. Partially offsetting these sequential improvements will be in Electronics, we expect demand to continue to remain strong. As we've discussed with you in the past, we plan to finalize our restructuring efforts in quarter three, which will result in higher cost next quarter. While margins will dip in quarter three, we expect them to rebound in quarter four and be on track to meet our 2011 goal of 15%.  In Equipment and Energy, we're forecasting higher energy development spending next quarter and planned maintenance outages at a number of plants. 
Looking at fiscal 2010 with half of the fiscal year behind us, we are raising our earnings per share guidance for the year. We were at $4.75 to $4.95 and are increasing our guidance to $4.90 to $5, anticipating earnings per share growth of 21% to 23% versus prior year. Overall, our 2010 economic assumptions haven't changed much. We expect that global manufacturing will still grow about 2% in our fiscal 2010. Regionally, Europe remains the weakest and we still expect the 1% decline in our fiscal 2010. North America should be up about 1% and Asia continues to be the strongest and we are now forecasting growth of about 10% in our fiscal 2010.
Demand in the electronics market has been strong, so we're modestly increasing our estimate for silicon growth to about 30%. Our capital spending guidance remains unchanged as well as most of our other assumptions. Despite the gradual nature of the recovery, we remain optimistic about our prospects for the future. 
Turning to other growth initiatives. As you all know, we announced our offer for Airgas earlier this quarter. Let me give you a brief update on where that stands. We remain convinced of the strong industrial logic and strong strategic rationale that underpinned this deal. We also believe that we are the best company to do this deal as our businesses are highly complementary. Air Products has no existing U.S. packaged gas business, which is 90% of Airgas. We remain confident in our ability to produce the substantial cost synergies we've identified, primarily relating to reductions in corporate overhead and company costs, supply-chain efficiencies and better utilization of infrastructure. Coupled with the enhanced growth opportunities we see, this deal creates significant value for our shareholders. Despite the highly attractive nature of our all cash 38% premium offer and our repeated attempts to engage the Airgas board in discussions, they have refused to engage with us. Therefore, we took the next step and commenced a tender offer, taking our offer directly to the Airgas shareholders. Our next step will be the submission of our shareholder proposals for consideration at Airgas' 2010 annual meeting. This will include our alternative slate of directors and other proposals designed to allow Airgas' shareholders to decide for themselves about our offer. We have also been in discussions with the Federal Trade Commission. We are working cooperatively with the FTC to answer their questions and to provide information.
Our regulatory approval strategy and shareholder actions are designed to ensure that Airgas shareholders have the opportunity to send a clear and unambiguous message to their board at the 2010 annual meeting, which Airgas has disclosed in recent SEC filings will be held no later than September 17. We believe that our offer represents excellent value to the Airgas shareholders, well above the $43.53 price Airgas shares were trading at on the day before the offer. I want to be clear that we will not overpay for Airgas. We are disciplined and we will remain disciplined as we bring this deal to a conclusion. We will not sacrifice the excellent growth prospects we have in our existing businesses. We will continue to fully fund and resource these many opportunities. Our cash-generating capabilities and reinvestment opportunities remain very strong. Acquiring Airgas would not impact our growth, margin improvement and earnings goals. It provides upside.
In short, Air Products shareholders should understand that we have a very bright future with or without Airgas. At the right price, this is one of our many excellent growth opportunities. Now let me wrap up. We continue to make solid progress towards our goal of improving operating margins and returns and we remain focused on these goals. We believe that our goal to become a low-cost supplier versus our competitors enables us to deliver greater growth and higher returns, resulting in significant increases in shareholder value. We are pursuing numerous growth opportunities around the world. As the economy recovers, we have significant operating leverage in our businesses. Regardless of the outcome of the Airgas offer, we are well-positioned to continue to create shareholder value. The whole team in Air Products is excited and energized by the many opportunities we have. Thank you and now I'll turn the call over to Tricka to take your questions.

componenttextpreview: On the Merchant business, if I may, first on the volume side, I was wondering if you could comment on what you're seeing in the month of April and then on pricing, sounds like liquid argon is down. Would you comment on how much that's off and if we adjust
componenttext: On the Merchant business, if I may, first on the volume side, I was wondering if you could comment on what you're seeing in the month of April and then on pricing, sounds like liquid argon is down. Would you comment on how much that's off and if we adjust for that and other elements, what is LOX-LIN pricing doing on an underlying basis?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, this is Nelson. Volumes continue strong in the month of April, pretty much across-the-board. So we're seeing, March was a particularly strong month for the business. It typically is one of the two strongest months in the fiscal year and so that pla
componenttext: Kevin, this is Nelson. Volumes continue strong in the month of April, pretty much across-the-board. So we're seeing, March was a particularly strong month for the business. It typically is one of the two strongest months in the fiscal year and so that played out as expected. So volumes continue the momentum into April. From a pricing standpoint, our costs were essentially flat quarter on quarter. The argon was really just the impact of bringing some new capacity onstream that basically took pricing down a little bit. But if I look at LOX-LIN, in pretty much every region, it's flat to slightly up. We continue to get some pricing in China where we're trying to recover against energy increases. And so we're seeing the most impact again from the liquid argon in Asia. For liquid hydrogen in North America because natural gas prices are lower and that's a little bit of a lag effect on the price. But the underlying pricing story is still holding together pretty well.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, just to add to the comment which Nelson had, we did have the $0.09 down in pricing, which people saw which is a quarter to prior year impact. Sequentially, our pricing impact was about flat on earnings.
componenttext: Kevin, just to add to the comment which Nelson had, we did have the $0.09 down in pricing, which people saw which is a quarter to prior year impact. Sequentially, our pricing impact was about flat on earnings.

componenttext: To what degree you can offer some help in terms of your comments on Airgas and the focus on not overpaying and the right value. What are you looking at in terms of that? Is it return on capital basis, cash flow, I just wanted to get a little feel for your outlook on that?

componenttextpreview: Return on capital and cash flow are actually the same because you put cash out and you get cash back with those things. So it is driven by the return in which we're looking there by the investment in Airgas. And we think we create a significant amount of
componenttext: Return on capital and cash flow are actually the same because you put cash out and you get cash back with those things. So it is driven by the return in which we're looking there by the investment in Airgas. And we think we create a significant amount of value by buying them. But we're not going to share every dollar of that. We certainly are willing to share a portion of that with the Airgas shareholders. But for right now, we are focused really on the offer that's out there and moving that the gain, seeing that represents a very good value to the Airgas shareholders.

componenttext: Don, this is Nelson. As you look into the rest of the year, certainly, we see a decent pickup in LOX-LIN volumes in North America in the second half of the year, something probably in the neighborhood of 3% or so. We think that trend will begin to improve in Europe although as we said previously, we think it still remains pretty weak. And we continue to see pretty solid growth in Asia. We are bringing new capacity onstream throughout Asia, which of course is planned in the sequence of doing that. But we should see a volume pickup in the second half of the year. Certainly, in North America, continuing in Asia. And if anything, flat to slightly up in Europe as we go forward.

componenttext: Sequentially, pricing is probably flat to slightly up. And I'm really referring to LOX-LIN. I would say that because obviously, liquid hydrogen was impacted by lower nat gas costs. Quality new signings is stable. It's rebounding off of the bottom that we saw somewhere at around four or five quarters ago. And so we're happy with the quality of signings.

componenttext: Question on Tonnage, your volumes were up 11% but earnings were up only 9% in margins were actually down. So the question is, why are you seeing more leverage in operating income line?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: PJ, we still had a lot of costs in the maintenance area in this year, a lot of customer turnarounds for us. And so that's something which we're seeing, which pulls our earnings down. Now the maintenance costs are going to come off in quarter three and qua
componenttext: PJ, we still had a lot of costs in the maintenance area in this year, a lot of customer turnarounds for us. And so that's something which we're seeing, which pulls our earnings down. Now the maintenance costs are going to come off in quarter three and quarter four. And you'll see improvements there.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010

componenttext: How many got delayed? If you take a look at that, we have had probably three or four of them, which had pushed back from what their original timing was for us. As far as the projects which we're bringing onstream this year, we have not seen delays pretty much. The delays have more occurred for projects which have already been put into our outlook and stuff like that but things which were coming on beyond 2010.

componenttext: Are we bringing in the capital spending at the same rate? It is pretty close to that right now. Award activity probably has run down the backlog a little bit for us right now because award activity has been slow. However, as we look towards jobs which we would expect to sign contracts on in the last half of the year, we would expect that and that we would replace or exceed a little bit the projects which actually come off this year.

componenttext: I don't think we had a -- and I might have one or two but I think I'm pretty much out of that area right now.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was also hoping that you could comment on the big improvement in the Equipment and Energy margin. That margin number looks like about the highest you've shown in the last four or five years. I was wondering, I know there's choppiness in that business, b
componenttext: I was also hoping that you could comment on the big improvement in the Equipment and Energy margin. That margin number looks like about the highest you've shown in the last four or five years. I was wondering, I know there's choppiness in that business, but I'm wondering if you can comment on that and what should we be expecting going forward?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, and the explanation is pretty easy. If you look at sales in 2009 quarter two, we had a lot more in the air separation side and a lot less on the LNG side. This time, we had more on the LNG side and less on the air separation side. The LNG profi
componenttext: Yes, Mike, and the explanation is pretty easy. If you look at sales in 2009 quarter two, we had a lot more in the air separation side and a lot less on the LNG side. This time, we had more on the LNG side and less on the air separation side. The LNG profitability is higher because I have a complete value-added component to that where I pass-through a lot of compression equipment and stuff like that, which I purchased on the air separation side. And so it's really a mix between air separation and the LNG and more LNG this quarter.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on Merchant pricing in Asia. You've shown kind of three straight quarters here with negative year-over-year pricing. How big of a margin impact have you seen due to that pricing decline over that time and should we expect to see pricing a
componenttext: I had a question on Merchant pricing in Asia. You've shown kind of three straight quarters here with negative year-over-year pricing. How big of a margin impact have you seen due to that pricing decline over that time and should we expect to see pricing and margin improvement given the strong demand that you've seen in Asia?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with the pricing coming down, it's obviously been a small impact to the margins in Merchant area. But as you can see, overall our margins in that area are up and will continue to go up. We would expect them to return to like a Q1 level in quarter th
componenttext: Well, with the pricing coming down, it's obviously been a small impact to the margins in Merchant area. But as you can see, overall our margins in that area are up and will continue to go up. We would expect them to return to like a Q1 level in quarter three but overall for the year, we're going to have a good margin in that area. And so that's going to also be helped as we lap some of the declines in LAR in Merchant pricing.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give me some sense on Electronics and Performance, how long do you expect these very strong sequential numbers to continue and maybe talk a little bit about the seasonality there?
componenttext: Can you give me some sense on Electronics and Performance, how long do you expect these very strong sequential numbers to continue and maybe talk a little bit about the seasonality there?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the Electronics and Performance Materials, there is a sequential uptick from quarter two to quarter three and we would expect to see that. And so I would expect to see a good quarter three and a good Q4. And then we'll probably see a start of th
componenttext: As far as the Electronics and Performance Materials, there is a sequential uptick from quarter two to quarter three and we would expect to see that. And so I would expect to see a good quarter three and a good Q4. And then we'll probably see a start of the sequential down in quarter one. You'll realize that the business here took the highest hit from the recession. And so it's going to have the strongest bounce back, also coming through here.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to add Bob, this is Nelson. Certainly, the improved automobile production has helped the Performance Materials business. And as I said during the call, or during the prepared remarks, one of the things that was very encouraging was we did take a li
componenttext: I want to add Bob, this is Nelson. Certainly, the improved automobile production has helped the Performance Materials business. And as I said during the call, or during the prepared remarks, one of the things that was very encouraging was we did take a little bit of a volume hit during lunar new year but we were up sequentially. So customer operating rates have continued to improve and key customer rates are over 80% now. So that number we think as Paul said, continues to track up for the next two quarters.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question, Laurence Alexander with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question, Laurence Alexander with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give an update on how you're thinking about the hydrogen market, both in terms of any large projects coming, which might be up for bid over the next four to six quarters? And also what you think the longer-term CAGR for demand might be or the ad
componenttext: Could you give an update on how you're thinking about the hydrogen market, both in terms of any large projects coming, which might be up for bid over the next four to six quarters? And also what you think the longer-term CAGR for demand might be or the addressable CAGR for Air Products?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we take a look on the hydrogen area, we do see a move outside the U.S. into places like Asia, the Middle East for us. We currently are actively involved in projects out there. And so we think that the growth for hydrogen is still going to be somewhere
componenttext: If we take a look on the hydrogen area, we do see a move outside the U.S. into places like Asia, the Middle East for us. We currently are actively involved in projects out there. And so we think that the growth for hydrogen is still going to be somewhere around 8% to 10% range. But the shift is going to be for the bulk of the market to be outside of the U.S. as far as work is concerned. And less growth within North America in the near term. There's still the oil sands, which could produce more growth if that gets developed.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the pace of outsourcing activity to be the same in Asia as in the U.S.?
componenttext: And do you expect the pace of outsourcing activity to be the same in Asia as in the U.S.?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the outsourcing in Asia, we think on the majors, we think it's going to be doable. I think you're going to see some JVs in China to make these things happen also.
componenttext: On the outsourcing in Asia, we think on the majors, we think it's going to be doable. I think you're going to see some JVs in China to make these things happen also.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And separately, can you give a little bit more detail on demand trends in Europe, particular end markets that might be stronger or are recovering earlier? And are there any other areas where you're surprised by how weak it is?
componenttext: And separately, can you give a little bit more detail on demand trends in Europe, particular end markets that might be stronger or are recovering earlier? And are there any other areas where you're surprised by how weak it is?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: For us, in the European business, the place in which we have seen the lowest margin declines is packaged gas. Packaged gas is a late cycle as far as the business is concerned. And so our bulk market, and our bulk volumes have been doing pretty well and co
componenttext: For us, in the European business, the place in which we have seen the lowest margin declines is packaged gas. Packaged gas is a late cycle as far as the business is concerned. And so our bulk market, and our bulk volumes have been doing pretty well and coming back. A lot of business in the food area has been performing well for us. If you look at the geography of it, the East and the North are probably better than the South in Europe. The South is still pretty much in a tough recession at this point in time.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Mann with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Mann with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that the operating below the take or pay minimum in the quarter. Did that ratio change at all from the first quarter to the second quarter? So did you grow volumes in your plants take or pay minimum? What I'm trying to get is whether or not
componenttext: You mentioned that the operating below the take or pay minimum in the quarter. Did that ratio change at all from the first quarter to the second quarter? So did you grow volumes in your plants take or pay minimum? What I'm trying to get is whether or not as you go forward, do you feel better incremental margin for coming from coming in from tonnage because you more take or pay minimum, if that makes sense?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, for the people operating above the take or pay, we probably have some of that. The place which is going to impact us and the most of our products is still on the hydrogen area for us. And that's the bulk of our business in the tonnage area. And so w
componenttext: Paul, for the people operating above the take or pay, we probably have some of that. The place which is going to impact us and the most of our products is still on the hydrogen area for us. And that's the bulk of our business in the tonnage area. And so we really didn't see our customers go to the mins in that area. Our customers have still continued to cooperate. Our volumes year on year in that area are about flat with those things, if I take out the new plants when you look at it. We have seen on the steel on sites, we have seen increases in the volumes. Realize that for a lot of our customers in steel, it is a take or pay contract. It is a type of contract. I don't pay for the plant and then I pace per product charge. I typically make all of my money on the payment for the plant and not on the product charge that pass through the energy. So I don't have a lot of volatility in the business introduced by the steel aspect of it.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the, if you put in your volumes from Q1 into Q2 trying to bring them up to the take or pay minimum, you're not going to see a revenue on margin impact. And if you start to grow volumes going into Q3, I'm assuming we'll start to see a better revenue and
componenttext: On the, if you put in your volumes from Q1 into Q2 trying to bring them up to the take or pay minimum, you're not going to see a revenue on margin impact. And if you start to grow volumes going into Q3, I'm assuming we'll start to see a better revenue and margin impact.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What happens Paul, is actually and when a person operates at the men's, he doesn't pay the product charge which is just a pass through. And so actually, on the sales dollars come down, the profits tend not to come down, right. And therefore, what happens
componenttext: What happens Paul, is actually and when a person operates at the men's, he doesn't pay the product charge which is just a pass through. And so actually, on the sales dollars come down, the profits tend not to come down, right. And therefore, what happens is that the margins as they loading starts to occur up to the take or pay and above it is margins tend to decline a little bit with that. The bulk of the profits in this business is earned by installing a plant, having a plant operate for the customers. And that's where we operate at.

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking forward to sort of 2011, based on your backlog at the moment and the orders you're bidding for, would you expect CapEx to increase in 2011 or decrease or stay roughly the same?
componenttext: Just looking forward to sort of 2011, based on your backlog at the moment and the orders you're bidding for, would you expect CapEx to increase in 2011 or decrease or stay roughly the same?

headline: Air Products & Chemicals Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, I would expect that my CapEx probably would be the same to up in 2011. A lot of that is going to be dependent upon award activity here in the last six months.
componenttext: Right now, I would expect that my CapEx probably would be the same to up in 2011. A lot of that is going to be dependent upon award activity here in the last six months.
